contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

Badges are used to indicate a notification, item count, or other information relating to a navigation destination. They are placed on the ending edge of icons, typically within other components.

There are 2 types of badges:

  1. Small badge
  2. Large badge

contentChunks.footer: Navigation bar with four badges.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 4 badges in different configurations on a navigation bar's destination icons.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
A small badge is a simple circle, used to indicate an unread notification.

A large badge contains label text communicating item count information.

contentChunks.footer: Small badge.
contentChunks.altText: A small badge is a circle with no characters

contentChunks.footer: Large badge.
contentChunks.altText: A large badge holds four characters and expands its container's width but not height.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
With other components

Badges are most commonly used within other components, such as navigation bar, navigation rail, top app bars, and tabs.

contentChunks.footer: In navigation bars, hide the badge once the destination has been selected.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation bar showing focused destination without a badge because the active destination badge is not seen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

There are 2 container types for the badge. Small badge (with no text) and large badge (with text).

contentChunks.footer: A small badge uses only shape to indicate a status change or new notification.
A large badge displays a number within a container to indicate a quantifiable status change related to a destination.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Badge containers are anchored inside the icon bounding box. As the number count increases for large badges, their width expands, but keeps the same placement.

Badges use a color intended to stand out against labels, icons, and navigation elements. Use the default color mapping to avoid color conflict issues.Â

contentChunks.footer: Change the position of the badge for right-to-left languages.
Badges have fixed positions. Donât change the position of the badge arbitrarily or place the badge over the icon.
Use the default badge color.
Avoid using custom color mappings for the badge container and label text. They may not meet accessibility requirements.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Label large badges with counts or a status. The maximum number of characters within large badge label text is four, including a + to indicate more.
Use the recommended maximum character count to ensure labels donât extend beyond the badge container.

contentChunks.footer: Truncate badge labels as needed.
Donât let the badge get cut off or collide with another element.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement

contentChunks.footer: Use a large badge to show count information when visual collisions arenât an issue, such as in a navigation drawer.
Use a small badge when spaces are tightly constrained, such as top app bars. Small badges wonât run into the edge of the screen.
contentChunks.altText: a small badge appearing on the last top app bar navigation icon, closest to the edge of the UI screen

contentChunks.footer: Place badges on the ending edge of a lockup to avoid visual collisions.
Avoid using a large badge when it might overlap with a trailing element. Either place it at the ending edge of the lockup or use a small badge instead.
